oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Good Luck to the American Soldiers in the Philippines
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Broadside lithograph features photographs of a company of American soldiers, with the men photographed in threes and set into a large blue horseshoe design ornamented with gold stars and topped by an eagle. A central photograph shows an unidentified soldier and also features a partially printed blank service form. Background features soldiers in action or marching and a Philippine village.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Broadsides
Broadsides; Philippines - History - Philippine-American War, 1899-1902; Soldiers
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Herbert E. Ellsworth
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Philippine-American War began in 1899 when revolutionary leader Emilio Aguinaldo declared war on the United States with principal fighting ending in 1902. Lithographs of this type were printed in various configurations throughout the Philippine-American War.
